title: Samson's Vengeance
shortSummary: Judges 15 recounts Samson's fierce retaliation against the Philistines after they wrongfully take his wife and kill her father. Empowered by the Spirit of the Lord, Samson delivers a mighty victory, demonstrating God's strength working through him despite Israel's oppression. This chapter highlights themes of divine empowerment, justice, and God's provision in times of distress.
timeline: c. 1100 BC - Period of the Judges, during Israel's oppression by the Philistines

keyCharacters.name: Samson
keyCharacters.description: A Nazirite judge of Israel known for his supernatural strength, who seeks vengeance against the Philistines for their wrongs against him.

keyCharacters.name: Samson's wife
keyCharacters.description: The Timnite woman initially given to Samson, then given to another man by her father, sparking the conflict.

keyCharacters.name: Father of Samson's wife
keyCharacters.description: The Timnite man who refuses Samson access to his wife and gives her to another, igniting Samson's anger.

keyCharacters.name: Men of Judah
keyCharacters.description: Fellow Israelites who attempt to bind Samson and deliver him to the Philistines, showing internal conflict within Israel.

keyCharacters.name: Philistines
keyCharacters.description: Israel's oppressors who retaliate against Samson and seek to capture him, representing the enemy nation.

definitions.definition: A young goat; Samson brought a kid as a gift when visiting his wife.
Burning sticks or pieces of wood used to set fire to crops, symbolizing destruction and judgment.
An expression meaning to strike with great force and thoroughness.
The jawbone of a donkey used by Samson as an improvised weapon to slay a thousand men.
Meaning 'spring of the caller,' the name given to the place where God provided water to Samson.

outline.heading: Samson Denied His Wife and His Fiery Retaliation
outline.description: Samson visits his wife but is refused access by her father, who gives her to another man. In response, Samson catches 300 foxes, ties them tail-to-tail with firebrands, and burns the Philistines' crops, provoking their wrath.

outline.heading: Samson's Vengeance Against the Philistines
outline.description: Samson vows to be avenged and strikes the Philistines with great slaughter, then retreats to the rock of Etam, demonstrating God's strength through him.

outline.heading: The Men of Judah Bind Samson
outline.description: The Philistines camp in Judah, seeking Samson. The men of Judah capture him to hand him over, but they swear not to kill him, showing internal Israelite tension.

outline.heading: Samson's Mighty Deliverance and Provision
outline.description: The Spirit of the Lord empowers Samson to break free from his bonds and slay a thousand Philistines with a donkey's jawbone. Thirsty afterward, God miraculously provides water, reviving him.

outline.heading: Samson Judges Israel
outline.description: The chapter concludes by noting Samson's twenty-year judgeship over Israel during Philistine oppression, highlighting his role as deliverer.

application: Trust in God's empowerment when facing overwhelming opposition, just as Samson was strengthened by the Spirit of the Lord.
Seek God's provision in times of physical and spiritual thirst, remembering that He sustains His servants in their trials.
Respond to injustice with righteous zeal, but always rely on God’s guidance rather than personal strength alone.
Be cautious of internal divisions within the community of believers, as seen in Judah’s attempt to bind Samson.

keyVerses.text: And when he came unto Lehi, the Philistines shouted against him: and the Spirit of the LORD came mightily upon him, and the cords that were upon his arms became as flax that was burnt with fire, and his bands loosed from off his hands.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the divine empowerment that enables Samson to overcome human constraints and enemies.

keyVerses.text: And he found a new jawbone of an ass, and put forth his hand, and took it, and slew a thousand men therewith.
keyVerses.significance: Demonstrates how God can use unexpected means to accomplish mighty victories through His servants.

keyVerses.text: But God clave an hollow place that was in the jaw, and there came water thereout; and when he had drunk, his spirit came again, and he revived: wherefore he called the name thereof Enhakkore, which is in Lehi unto this day.
keyVerses.significance: Shows God's provision and restoration for His servant in moments of desperate need.
